author: Deborah Martin
title: ‘Beauty and the Beast’ returns to the Majestic
text:
Photo: Courtesy Matthew Murphy Image 1 of / 1 1 Brooke Quintana as Belle and Sam Hartley as the Beast in Disney's “Beauty and the Beast.” Brooke Quintana as Belle and Sam Hartley as the Beast in Disney's “Beauty and the Beast.” Photo: Courtesy Matthew Murphy ‘Beauty and the Beast’ returns to the Majestic 1 / 1 Back to Gallery Brooke Quintana , who plays Belle in the touring production of “Beauty and the Beast” that hits the Majestic Theatre this weekend, is not supposed to watch the “Human Again” number.
During the scene, in which objects that were once people sing of their desire to return to their human form, Quintana’s character is in the library, seemingly unaware of the goings-on elsewhere in the castle.
“I’m always side-eyeing to watch the beautiful dancing,” she said in a telephone interview from a tour stop in her native North Carolina. “It makes me very emotional. It’s all they want, is to live their lives, and you see that humanity. I think that’s a big part of the show, seeing past the exterior. It gets me every time. I really love that.”
More Information On stage
What: Touring production of “Beauty and the Beast”
When: 8 p.m. today, 2 and 8 p.m. Saturday, 2 and 7:30 p.m. Sunday,
Where: Majestic Theatre, 224 E. Houston St.
Tickets: $35-$95 box office, 210-226-5700; additional fees applied to tickets purchased at ticketmaster.com.
The show is a stage adaptation of the Oscar-winning 1991 Disney movie about the unlikely romance that develops between brave young bookworm Belle and the Beast, who lives in an enchanted castle.
Both Quintana and Sam Hartley , who plays the Beast, remember first connecting with their characters as children.
Belle was Quintana’s favorite Disney princess growing up. And she still has a photo of herself as a 4-year-old wearing a Belle costume that her mother made for her.
“I think I always loved Belle because she is the hero in the story,” she said. “She’s not a damsel in distress. She is a strong, intelligent woman and a role model.”
Hartley was about that same age when he first saw the movie, and said he remembers a VHS copy of it being “well-beloved in my household.
“As strange as this is, there’s a song that’s called ‘Something There,’ and I remember getting emotional about it at a young age, I don’t know if I understood why that was, but I can picture it: I’m sitting in day care on a couch and being struck by it. And one of the rewarding parts of doing the show now is, I’m 27 and I’m getting to approach the show from an adult perspective.”
